page.title: List of National Parks of Canada

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Canada provinces map|width=250px|map=Canadian National Parks.png|prefix=List of protected areas of|the=the|caption=Parks in Canada's provinces and territories}} [[Canada]]'s [[National Parks of Canada|National Parks]] are [[protected area]]s under the ''[[National Parks Act (Canada)|Canada National Parks Act]]'', owned by the [[Government of Canada]] and administered for the benefit, education, and enjoyment of the people of Canada and its future generations.{{cite web |url= http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/N-14.01/FullText.html |title=''Canada National Parks Act'' S.C. 2000, c. 32 |date=October 12, 2000 |accessdate=January 25, 2018 |publisher=Government of Canada}} National parks are administered by [[Parks Canada]], a [[Crown corporations of Canada|Crown agency]] operating under the jurisdiction of the [[Environment and Climate Change Canada|Ministry of Environment and Climate Change]]. The goal of the national parks system is to set aside lands representing the country's 39 distinct natural regions described in the ''National Parks System Plan'', primarily to protect the ecological integrity of the land, and secondarily to allow the public to explore, learn about and enjoy Canada's natural spaces.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/introduction|title=National Parks of Canada – Introduction|publisher=Parks Canada|accessdate=13 December 2017}} Canada's first national park was created in 1885 through an [[Order in Council|Order-in-Council]]{{cite web |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/databases/orders/001022-119.01-e.php?&sisn_id_nbr=30445&page_sequence_nbr=1&interval=20&&page_id_nbr=95575&&&&PHPSESSID=crnkuooiktn602a9dnufmjbqg9mkba443c57qcpm9nspau4g8f40 |publisher=Library and Archives Canada |title=Order-in-Council #2197-1885 |date=November 25, 1885 |accessdate=January 24, 2018}} to reserve {{cvt|26|sqkm}} over the [[Cave and Basin National Historic Site|Cave and Basin Hot Springs]] to prevent the land from being sold for private development despite claims being made for it. Modeled after the American experience with [[Yellowstone National Park]], the ''Rocky Mountains Park Act'', adopted in 1887, established the Rocky Mountains Park (now [[Banff National Park]]).{{cite book |title= A Brief History of Canada's National Parks |last=Lothian |first= W.F. |url= http://parkscanadahistory.com/publications/history/lothian/brief/eng/brief-history.pdf |publisher= Environment Canada |date=1981 |isbn= 0-662-15217-4 |accessdate=January 24, 2018}} The idea of a national park was popular and led to numerous proposals for the [[Minister of the Interior (Canada)|Ministry of the Interior]] to consider, including additional sites along the [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] (e.g. Yoho and Glacier and an expansion of Banff) and the [[Grand Trunk Pacific Railway]] (e.g. Jasper). In 1911 the ''Rocky Mountains Park Act'' was replaced by the ''Dominion Forest Reserves and Parks Act'' which created the world's first national parks service, the Dominion Parks Branch, to administer national parks in Canada.{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/travel/northamerica/article/990243--parks-canada-celebrates-a-century-of-discovery|title=Parks Canada celebrates a century of discovery|last=Irish|first=Paul|date=13 May 2011|work=Toronto Star|accessdate=24 January 2018}} These early national parks, including those established under the leadership of [[James Bernard Harkin|JB Harkin]] who was the first commissioner of the Dominion Parks Branch, were set aside to reserve lands principally for tourism and conservation but also had an exclusionary policy prohibiting [[First Nations]] peoples from using their traditional lands within the new parks.{{cite journal|authors=Binnema, Theodore; Niemi, Melanie |title='Let the line be drawn now': Wilderness, Conservation, and the Exclusion of Aboriginal People from Banff National Park in Canada|journal=Environmental History|year=2006|volume=11|issue=4|pages=724–50|doi=10.1093/envhis/11.4.724}} In 1922, [[Wood Buffalo National Park]] was the first to allow traditional indigenous activities to continue. In 1972, Parks Canada defined National Park Reserves, lands administered by the agency intended to become National Parks pending settlement of [[Aboriginal title in Canada|indigenous land rights]] and agreements for continued traditional use of the lands.{{cite web |url=https://www.ictinc.ca/blog/can-first-nations-hunt-in-national-parks |title=Can First Nations hunt in national parks? |first=Bob |last=Joseph |publisher=Indigenous Corporate Training, Inc. |date=13 March 2015 |accessdate=24 January 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/agence-agency/aa-ia/faits-facts|title=Indigenous fact sheet|publisher=Parks Canada|date=23 June 2017|accessdate=13 December 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171211231012/https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/agence-agency/aa-ia/faits-facts|archivedate=11 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} {{as of|2018}} there are 39 National Parks and eight National Park Reserves, covering an area of approximately {{cvt|328198|sqkm}},{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/cnpn-cnnp/carte-map-txt |title=The system of national parks of Canada |publisher=Parks Canada |date=10 January 2018 |accessdate=24 January 2018}} or about 3.3% of the total land area of Canada, and representing 30 of the 39 natural regions. There is at least one park located in every one of the nation's [[Provinces and territories of Canada|13 provinces and territories]]. Parks Canada reported attendance of 15,449,249 at all National Parks and Reserves in 2016–17, including over four million visits to the busiest park (Banff) and only two persons at the least-visited park ([[Tuktut Nogait National Park|Tuktut Nogait]]).{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/docs/pc/attend |title=Parks Canada Attendance 2016–17 |publisher=Parks Canada |date=11 September 2017 |accessdate=25 January 2018}} Parks Canada additionally manages three [[National Marine Conservation Area]]s (NMCAs), a single NMCA Reserve, and the country's lone [[National Landmarks (Canada)|National Landmark]]. The ''Canada National Parks Act'' also allows for recognition of [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Sites]] that commemorate events, landmarks, or objects of national importance, and which may include similar levels of protection and administration as national parks. Feasibility studies are underway to establish further national parks in unrepresented regions.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/cnpn-cnnp|title=Creating new national parks|publisher=Parks Canada|accessdate=13 December 2017|df=}} {{TOC limit|limit=2}} ==National Parks and National Park Reserves== National Park Reserves are indicated by "(Reserve)" after the park name. *{{Legend|#cfecd2|‡ [[List of World Heritage Sites in Canada|World Heritage Site]]|outline=silver}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" width="95%" |- !scope=col width=12%|Name !scope=col width=1%px class="unsortable"|Photo !scope=col width=8%|Location !scope=col width=8%|Established !scope=col width=8%|Area (2017) !scope=col width=8%|Natural region{{cite book |title=National Parks System Plan |author=Parks Canada |url=http://publications.gc.ca/collections/Collection/R64-197-1-1997E.pdf |year=1997 |isbn=0-662-25334-5}} !scope=col width=18% class="unsortable"|Description |- ! scope=row|[[Mealy Mountains National Park Reserve|Akami-Uapishkᵁ-KakKasuak-Mealy Mountains]]
(Reserve) | [[Image:Mealy Mountains Labrador 1.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Newfoundland and Labrador}}
{{coord|53|24|N|59|22|W|format=dms|name=Akami-Uapishk-KakKasuak-Mealy Mountains National Park|region:CA-NL_type:landmark}} | 2015 | {{sort|{{commas|10700}}|{{convert|10700|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | East coast boreal | The park includes a portion of the glacially-rounded [[Mealy Mountains]] on [[Labrador]] from [[Lake Melville]] to [[Sandwich Bay (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Sandwich Bay]] and includes some sandy beaches along the coast of the [[Labrador Sea]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Aulavik National Park|Aulavik]] | | {{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{coord|73|42|N|119|55|W|format=dms|name=Aulavik National Park|region:CA-NT_type:landmark}} | 1992 | {{sort|{{commas|12200}}|{{convert|12200|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Western arctic lowlands | Located on the northern part of [[Banks Island]], the completely treeless [[polar desert]] of Aulavik is home to the world's largest concentration of [[muskox]]en, as well as the endangered [[Peary caribou]].{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nt/aulavik/info/natcul1 |title=Aulavik National Park – Natural Environment |publisher=Parks Canada |date=8 June 2017 |accessdate=13 December 2017}} |- ! scope=row|[[Auyuittuq National Park|Auyuittuq]] | [[Image:Pangnirtung Fiord S 2 2001-07-15.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Nunavut}}
{{coord|67|53|N|65|01|W|format=dms|name=Auyuittuq National Park|region:CA-NU_type:landmark}} | 2001 | {{sort|{{commas|19089}}|{{convert|19089|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Northern Davis region | One of Canada's largest parks and located almost entirely within the [[Arctic Circle]], Auyuittuq on [[Baffin Island]] preserves a rugged arctic wilderness featuring some of the highest peaks of the [[Canadian Shield]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/auyuittuq/info |title=Auyuittuq National Park – About |publisher=Parks Canada |date=1 December 2017 |accessdate=14 December 2017}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Banff National Park|Banff]]‡ | [[Image:Moraine Lake 17092005.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Alberta}}
{{coord|51|30|N|116|0|W|format=dms|name=Banff National Park|region:CA-AB_type:landmark}} | 1885 | {{sort|{{commas|6641}}|{{convert|6641|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Rocky Mountains | The first park established by the federal government of Canada, Banff includes the [[Valley of the Ten Peaks]], the [[Wapta Icefield|Wapta]] and [[Waputik Icefield]]s, several ski resorts, and the communities of [[Lake Louise, Alberta|Lake Louise]] and [[Banff, Alberta|Banff]]. It is part of the [[Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks World Heritage Site]] and adjacent to the Kootenay and Yoho National Parks, and its boundary with the Jasper National Park at [[Snow Dome (Canada)|Snow Dome]] is a hydrological apex of North America. |- ! scope=row|[[Bruce Peninsula National Park|Bruce Peninsula]] | [[Image:CyprusLake - Bruce Peninsula.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|45|14|N|81|37|W|format=dms|name=Bruce Peninsula National Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 1987 | {{sort|{{commas|125}}|{{convert|125|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence lowlands | Formed from lands previously designated Ontario's Cyprus Lake Provincial Park, Bruce preserves a unique shoreline formation of the [[Niagara Escarpment]] and forms part of the larger UNESCO [[Niagara Escarpment Biosphere Reserve]]. The [[Bruce Trail]], one of Canada's longest hiking trails, passes through the park. The locally threatened [[Massasauga|massasauga rattlesnake]] is found within the park, as well as Canada's southernmost population of [[American black bear|black bear]]s.{{rp|142–143}} |- ! scope=row|[[Cape Breton Highlands National Park|Cape Breton Highlands]] | [[Image:NS CapeBretonHighlands1 tango7174.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Nova Scotia}}
{{coord|46|43|N|60|40|W|format=dms|name=Cape Breton Highlands National Park|region:CA-NS_type:landmark}} | 1936 | {{sort|{{commas|948}}|{{convert|948|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Maritime Acadian highlands | Atlantic Canada's oldest national park features [[Acadian forest|Acadian]] and [[boreal forest]] environments in the [[Cape Breton Highlands]]. One-third of the [[Cabot Trail]] passes through the central portion of the park. Most of Nova Scotia's population of [[Canada lynx]] are found in this park, and the endangered [[North Atlantic right whale]] is found in waters off the park's coast.{{rp|42–43}}{{cite news |title=Right whales off Cape Breton going the wrong way for shipping, fishing |url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/novascotia/1312707-right-whales-off-cape-breton-going-the-wrong-way-for-shipping-fishing |first=Tom |last=Ayers |newspaper=[[The Chronicle Herald]] |date=September 22, 2015 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}} [[Western moose]] were introduced to this park from Alberta's Elk Island National Park between 1947 and 1948, the native [[eastern moose]] having been hunted to near-extinction.{{cite web |title=Moose Management |url=https://novascotia.ca/abor/office/what-we-do/negotiations/moose-management/ |publisher=Nova Scotia Office of Aboriginal Affairs |date=February 2007 |accessdate=18 March 2018}} |- ! scope=row|[[Elk Island National Park|Elk Island]] | [[Image:Bison Elk Island.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Alberta}}
{{coord|53|37|N|112|52|W|format=dms|name=Elk Island National Park|region:CA-AB_type:landmark}} | 1913 | {{sort|{{commas|194}}|{{convert|194|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Southern boreal plains & plateaux | Created as a wildlife sanctuary for elk, the park has become a part of bison conservation, the [[Dark-sky preserve|Beaver Hills Dark Sky Preserve]], and the [[World Network of Biosphere Reserves in Europe and North America|Beaver Hills Biosphere Reserve]].{{cite book |title=Elk Island National Park of Canada Management Plan |year=2011 |publisher=Parks Canada |isbn= 978-1-100-18107-3}} Eighteen moose (nine males and nine females) from Elk Island were introduced to Nova Scotia's Cape Breton Highlands National Park between 1947 and 1948.{{cite web |title=Cape Breton Highlands National Park - Moose |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ns/cbreton/decouvrir-discover/faune-animals/mammiferes-mammals/orignal-moose |publisher=Parks Canada |date=3 January 2018 |accessdate=18 March 2018}} |- ! scope=row|[[Forillon National Park|Forillon]] | [[Image:Forillon National Park of Canada 1.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Quebec}}
{{coord|48|54|N|64|21|W|format=dms|name=Forillon National Park|region:CA-QC_type:landmark}} | 1970 | {{sort|{{commas|240}}|{{convert|240|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Notre Dame & Megantic Mountains | The lands of the first park in Quebec were traditional hunting and fishing grounds for the [[Mi'kmaq]] and [[Iroquois]], and were exploited for their rich supplies of lumber.{{rp|98–99}} Two hundred twenty-five families were controversially [[expropriated]] from the park lands prior to creation of the park in 1970. In 2011, the Government of Canada issued a formal apology to these families for their mistreatment.{{cite journal |title=The First French-Canadian National Parks: Kouchibouguac and Forillon in History and Memory |first=Ronald |last=Rudin |journal=Journal of the Canadian Historical Association |volume=22 |issue=1 |year=2011 |pages=161–200}} |- ! scope=row|[[Fundy National Park|Fundy]] | [[Image:Fundy NP New Brunswick 1.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|New Brunswick}}
{{coord|45|36|N|64|57|W|format=dms|name=Fundy National Park|region:CA-NB_type:landmark}} | 1948 | {{sort|{{commas|206}}|{{convert|206|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Maritime Acadian highlands | Featuring the highest [[tide]]s in the world, the [[Bay of Fundy]] exposes ocean floor at low tide which is covered by up to {{conv|16|m}} of salt water at high tide.{{cite web |title=Where is the highest tide? |url=https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/facts/highesttide.html |publisher=[[National Ocean Service]] |date=October 10, 2017 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}} The park forms the core portion of the UNESCO [[Fundy Biosphere Reserve]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Georgian Bay Islands National Park|Georgian Bay Islands]] | [[Image:BeausoleilIslandCedarSprings2004.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|44|53|N|79|52|W|format=dms|name=Georgian Bay Islands National Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 1930 | {{sort|{{commas|14}}|{{convert|14|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Great Lakes—St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence precambrian region | [[Beausoleil Island]] is the largest of the small islands which make up the park, which originally included [[Flowerpot Island]]. The islands form part of the UNESCO [[Georgian Bay Littoral|Georgian Bay Littoral Biosphere Reserve]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Glacier National Park (Canada)|Glacier]] | [[Image:Glacier np canada.JPG|175px|]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|51|18|N|117|31|W|format=dms|name=Glacier National Park|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 1886 | {{sort|{{commas|1349}}|{{convert|1349|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Columbia Mountains | Representative of the Columbia Mountains natural region, this park includes [[Illecillewaet Glacier]], [[Rogers Pass (British Columbia)|Rogers Pass]], [[Nakimu Caves]], [[Mount Sir Donald]], and [[Mount Dawson (Canada)|Mount Dawson]].{{cite book |title=State of the Parks Report – Mount Revelstoke and Glacier National Parks |publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |year=2008}} |- ! scope=row|[[Grasslands National Park|Grasslands]] | [[Image:Saskatchewan - Grasslands National Park 02.JPG|175px]] | {{flag|Saskatchewan}}
{{coord|49|12|N|107|43|W|format=dms|name=Grasslands National Park|region:CA-SK_type:landmark}} | 1981 | {{sort|{{commas|730}}|{{convert|730|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}
({{convert|905|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} proposed) | Prairie grasslands |Located along the borders with the American state of [[Montana]], the park features an undisturbed [[Grassland|mixed-grass prairie]] ecosystem and [[badlands]] where fossils from both the [[Frenchman Formation|Frenchman]] and [[Bearpaw Formation]]s were discovered including those of a [[Triceratops]] and a [[Tyrannosaurus]].{{cite book |title=Grasslands National Park Reserve of Canada Management Plan |year=2010 |publisher=Parks Canada |isbn= 978-1-100-15723-8}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Gros Morne National Park|Gros Morne]]‡ | [[File:NLW GrosMorne4 tango7174.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Newfoundland and Labrador}}
{{coord|49|41|N|57|44|W|format=dms|name=Gros Morne National Park|region:CA-NL_type:landmark}} | 1973 | {{sort|{{commas|1805}}|{{convert|1805|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Western Newfoundland highlands | A World Heritage Site due to its exposed [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] and [[Crust (geology)|crust]] as an example of [[plate tectonics]], the park also includes [[Western Brook Pond]], [[Lobster Cove, Newfoundland and Labrador|Lobster Cove]], and [[Gros Morne, Newfoundland|Gros Morne mountain]] in the [[Long Range Mountains]] chain.{{cite book |title=Gros Morne National Park of Canada Management Plan |year=2009 |publisher=Parks Canada |isbn= 0-662-44613-5}} |- ! scope=row|[[Gulf Islands National Park Reserve|Gulf Islands]]
(Reserve) | [[Image:Gulfislfromair.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|48|51|N|123|27|W|format=dms|name=Gulf Islands National Park Reserve|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 2003 | {{sort|{{commas|37}}|{{convert|37|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Strait of Georgia lowlands | Representative of the Strait of Georgia Lowlands, the park includes 6 km2 of marine environment and land on 15 islands.{{cite web |url=https://www.nationalgeographic.com/travel/parks/gulf-islands-canada-park/ |work=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |title=Gulf Islands National Park Reserve |accessdate=January 5, 2018}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve and Haida Heritage Site|Gwaii Haanas]]‡{{efn|South Moresby National Park Reserve was created 12 July 1988, with the signing of the South Moresby Agreement; renamed Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve and Haida Heritage Site on 28 February 1996. Includes SGaang Gwaii (Anthony Island) [[World Heritage Site]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0010322 |title=Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve and Haida Heritage Site|publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia|accessdate=7 April 2008}}}}
(Reserve) | [[Image:Haida Heritage Centre.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|52|23|N|131|28|W|format=dms|name=Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 1988 | {{sort|{{commas|1474}}|{{convert|1474|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Pacific coast mountains | Forming the southern end of the [[Haida Gwaii|Haida Gwaii archipelago]], the park is on the far western end of Canada and includes 138 islands, inclusive of [[Ninstints|Ninstints World Heritage Site]], [[Hotspring Island]], and the southern tip of [[Moresby Island]]. |- |scope=row|[[Ivvavik National Park|Ivvavik]]{{efn|Established as Northern Yukon National Park in 1984, renamed Ivvavik National Park in 1992.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/ivvavik-national-park/ |title=Ivvavik National Park|publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia|accessdate=7 April 2008}}}} | [[File:Sheep Slot Rapids, Firth River, Ivvavik National Park, YT.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Yukon}}
{{coord|69|31|N|139|31|W|format=dms|name=Ivvavik National Park|region:CA-YK_type:landmark}} | 1984 | {{sort|{{commas|9750}}|{{convert|9750|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Northern Yukon |Adjacent to Vuntut National Park and the American [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]], the park has arctic tundra that was not glaciated during the last ice age and consequently contains the oldest river in Canada, the Firth River. Ivvavik is the first national park created as a result of an aboriginal land claim agreement, the [[Inuvialuit Settlement Region|Inuvialuit Final Agreement]].{{cite book |title=Ivvavik National Park Management Plan |year=2017 |publisher=Parks Canada}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Jasper National Park|Jasper]]‡ | [[Image:Fryatt Valley top.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Alberta}}
{{coord|52|48|N|117|54|W|format=dms|name=Jasper National Park|region:CA-AB_type:landmark}} | 1907 | {{sort|{{commas|11228}}|{{convert|11228|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Rocky Mountains | Part of the [[Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks World Heritage Site]] and adjacent to the Banff National Parks, as well as [[Mount Robson Provincial Park|Mount Robson]] and [[Hamber Provincial Park]]s in British Columbia, this park includes the community of [[Jasper, Alberta|Jasper]], [[Columbia Icefield]], [[Athabasca Falls]], [[Sunwapta Falls]], [[Maligne Lake]], and [[Maligne Canyon|canyon]], and the [[Snow Dome (Canada)|Snow Dome]], a hydrological apex of North America, at its boundary with the Banff National Park. |- ! scope=row|[[Kejimkujik National Park|Kejimkujik]] | [[Image:Kejimkujik NP Nova Scotia 3.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Nova Scotia}}
{{coord|44|24|N|65|13|W|format=dms|name=Kejimkujik National Park|region:CA-NS_type:landmark}} | 1967 | {{sort|{{commas|404}}|{{convert|404|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Atlantic coast plain | The area around [[Kejimikujik Lake]] was acquired by the federal government for park purposes in 1967 and added a 22 km2 seaside component in 1985. The inland portion was designated a National Historic Site in 1995 recognizing its [[Mi'kmaq|Mi'kmaw]] cultural landscape and is adjacent to the [[Tobeatic Wilderness Area]]. The park is part of the [[Southwest Nova Biosphere Reserve]] and a [[dark-sky preserve]].{{cite book |title=Kejimkujik National Park and National Historic Site of Canada Management Plan |year=2010 |publisher=Parks Canada |isbn= 978-1-100-13549-6}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Kluane National Park and Reserve|Kluane]]‡{{efn|Kluane National Park Reserve was set aside in 1976, following the Kluane Game Reserve of the early 1940s. Subsequently, an eastern portion of the Reserve became Kluane National Park in 1993.}}
(two units: a Park and a Reserve) | [[Image:Donjek Valley.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Yukon}}
{{coord|60|37|N|138|20|W|format=dms|name=Kluane National Park and Reserve|region:CA-YK_type:landmark}} | 1972 (Reserve)
29 May 1993 (Park) | {{sort|{{commas|21980}}|{{convert|21980|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Northern coast mountains | Part of a [[Kluane / Wrangell–St. Elias / Glacier Bay / Tatshenshini-Alsek|World Heritage Site]] and adjacent to the American [[Wrangell–St. Elias National Park and Preserve|Wrangell–St. Elias National Park]] and British Columbian [[Tatshenshini-Alsek Provincial Park]], Kluane features the [[Mountain peaks of Canada|highest mountain peaks in Canada]], including [[Mount Logan]], and the largest non-polar ice field in the world.{{Cite web |url= http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-non-polar-ice-field/ |title=Largest non-polar ice field |accessdate=January 6, 2018 |year=2011 |publisher=[[Guinness World Records]]}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Kootenay National Park|Kootenay]]‡ | [[Image:Kootenay National Park.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|50|53|N|116|03|W|format=dms|name=Kootenay National Park|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 1920 | {{sort|{{commas|1406}}|{{convert|1406|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Rocky Mountains | Part of the [[Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks World Heritage Site]] and adjacent to the Banff and Yoho National Parks, as well as the [[Mount Assiniboine Provincial Park]], the park is representative of the Rocky Mountains natural region and includes the [[Radium Hot Springs]] pools, an outcrop of the [[Burgess Shale]] fossil deposit, [[Numa Falls]], and [[Floe Lake]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Kouchibouguac National Park|Kouchibouguac]] | [[Image:Kouchibouguac.JPG|175px]] | {{flag|New Brunswick}}
{{coord|46|51|N|64|58|W|format=dms|name=Kouchibouguac National Park|region:CA-NB_type:landmark}} | 1969 | {{sort|{{commas|239}}|{{convert|239|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Maritime plain | Located on the coast where the [[Kouchibouguac River]] enters the [[Northumberland Strait]], across from the north end of Prince Edward Island, the park illustrates [[Beach evolution|coastal dynamics]], including [[tidal river]]s, [[Dune|coastal dunes]], [[salt marsh]]es, [[bog]]s, and [[barrier island]]s.{{cite book |title=Kouchibouguac National Park of Canada Management Plan |publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |year=2010 |isbn= 978-1-100-13556-4 }} |- ! scope=row|[[La Mauricie National Park|La Mauricie]] | [[Image:Ile aux pins.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Quebec}}
{{coord|46|48|N|72|58|W|format=dms|name=La Mauricie National Park|region:CA-QC_type:landmark}} | 1970 | {{sort|{{commas|536}}|{{convert|536|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Great Lakes—St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence precambrian region | Located north of [[Shawinigan]], and between [[Saint-Maurice River]], [[Matawin River (Quebec)|Matawin River]], and [[Mastigouche Wildlife Reserve]], the park features a [[canoe camping]] circuit and habitat for the [[wood turtle]].{{cite book |title=La Mauricie National Park of Canada Management Plan |publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |year=2010 |isbn= 978-1-100-14153-4 }} |- ! scope=row|[[Mingan Archipelago National Park Reserve|Mingan Archipelago]]
(Reserve) | [[Image:Monolithes de L'Archipel de Mingan.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Quebec}}
{{coord|50|13|N|63|10|W|format=dms|name=Mingan Archipelago National Park Reserve|region:CA-QC_type:landmark}} | 1984 | {{sort|{{commas|151}}|{{convert|151|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence lowlands | Located along the [[Gulf of St. Lawrence]], the park consists of the [[Mingan Archipelago]] with its [[limestone]] [[outcrop]]s and [[Atlantic puffin]] habitat. |- ! scope=row|[[Mount Revelstoke National Park|Mount Revelstoke]] | [[Image:Revelstoke from Mount Revelstoke.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|51|05|N|118|04|W|format=dms|name=Mount Revelstoke National Park|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 1914 | {{sort|{{commas|262}}|{{convert|262|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Columbia Mountains | Accessible by a trail from the [[Revelstoke, British Columbia|City of Revelstoke]], the park is representative of the Columbia Mountains natural region. |- ! scope=row|[[Nááts'ihch'oh National Park Reserve|Nááts'ihch'oh]]
(Reserve) | [[File:Howard's Pass Yukon Territory 1.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{coord|62|22|N|127|58|W|format=dms|name=Nááts'ihch'oh National Park Reserve|region:CA-NT_type:landmark}} | 2014 | {{sort|{{commas|4850}}|{{convert|4850|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Mackenzie Mountains | Adjacent to the Nahanni National Park, Nááts'įhch'oh extends the protected area into the Sahtu Settlement Area to include additional land with the [[South Nahanni River]] watershed to Mount Nááts’įhch’oh and the [[Moose Ponds]].{{cite book |title=Nááts’įhch’oh National Park Reserve of Canada Management Plan |year=2017 |publisher=Parks Canada |isbn= 978-0-660-09423-6}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Nahanni National Park Reserve|Nahanni]]‡
(Reserve) | [[Image:Nahanni - VirginiaFalls.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{coord|61|33|N|125|35|W|format=dms|name=Nahanni National Park Reserve|region:CA-NT_type:landmark}} | 1972 | {{sort|{{commas|30000}}|{{convert|30000|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}{{efn|In 2007, the government announced that {{convert|29000|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} of land would be added to Nahanni, making it {{convert|33766|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}. However, these changes have not been fully implemented {{as of|2017|lc=y}}.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20070808/harper_arctic_070808/20070808?hub=Canada |title=Tories' expansion of Nahanni park praised |publisher=[[CTV Television Network]]|date=8 August 2007|accessdate=7 April 2008}}}} | Mackenzie Mountains | Containing the first natural [[List of World Heritage Sites in Canada|World Heritage Site]] in Canada, the park includes the [[South Nahanni River]], [[Virginia Falls (Northwest Territories)|Virginia Falls]], the [[Cirque of the Unclimbables]], and a limestone cave system.{{cite book |title=Nahanni National Park Reserve of Canada Nahʔą Dehé Management Plan |year=2010 |publisher=Parks Canada |isbn=978-1-100-15495-4}} |- ! scope=row|[[Pacific Rim National Park Reserve|Pacific Rim]]
(Reserve) | [[Image:Longbeach prnp.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|48|38|N|124|46|W|format=dms|name=Pacific Rim National Park Reserve|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 1970 | {{sort|{{commas|510}}|{{convert|510|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Pacific coast mountains | Representative of the coastal plain portion of the Pacific Coast Mountains natural region, the park is divided into three separated parts: [[Long Beach (British Columbia)|Long Beach]], the [[Broken Group]] islands, and the [[West Coast Trail]].{{cite book |title=State of the Parks Report – Pacific Rim National Park Reserve|publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-662-48932-0}} |- ! scope=row|[[Point Pelee National Park|Point Pelee]] | [[Image:Point Pelee looking south.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|41|58|N|82|31|W|format=dms|name=Point Pelee National Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 1918 | {{sort|{{commas|15}}|{{convert|15|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence lowlands | The first national park established for conservation, Point Pelee is the southernmost point of the Canadian mainland, and also includes the southernmost point overall on [[Middle Island (Lake Erie)|Middle Island]]. The marshy wetland environment is a known stop for migratory birds and [[monarch butterflies]],{{cite news |title=Monarch butterflies by the thousands at Point Pelee |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/windsor/monarch-butterflies-by-the-thousands-at-point-pelee-1.2769252 |publisher=CBC News |date=September 17, 2014 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}} and since 1987 is a [[Ramsar Convention]] Wetland of International Importance.{{cite web |url=https://rsis.ramsar.org/ris/368 |title=Point Pelee |website=Ramsar Sites Information Service |accessdate=January 10, 2018}} |- ! scope=row|[[Prince Albert National Park|Prince Albert]] | [[Image:Prince Albert National Park.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Saskatchewan}}
{{coord|53|58|N|106|22|W|format=dms|name=Prince Albert National Park|region:CA-SK_type:landmark}} | 1927 | {{sort|{{commas|3875}}|{{convert|3875|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Southern boreal plains & plateaux | Established with a [[Outdoor recreation|recreation focus]], the park includes a small community on the east end of [[Waskesiu Lake]] and features [[Festuca|fescue]] [[grasslands]] with [[plains bison]], [[Boreal forest of Canada|boreal forest]], and [[Ajawaan Lake|Ajawaan]], [[Lavallee Lake, Saskatchewan|Lavallee]], and other lakes.{{cite book |title=Prince Albert National Park Reserve Management Plan |publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |year=2017}} |- ! scope=row|[[Prince Edward Island National Park|Prince Edward Island]] | [[Image:Peicoast.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Prince Edward Island}}
{{coord|46|25|N|63|05|W|format=dms|name=Prince Edward Island National Park|region:CA-PE_type:landmark}} | 1937 | {{sort|{{commas|27}}|{{convert|27|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Maritime plain | Sensitive sand beaches and dunes on the island's north shore provide nesting habitat for the endangered [[piping plover]] and are designated an [[Important Bird Area]]. An extension added in 1998 protects [[Dune#Parabolic|parabolic sand dunes]] and an area with archaeological evidence of [[Paleo-Indian]] occupation up to 10,000 years ago.{{cite journal |title=A Story Written in Sand |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=_z-UqTVBfyAC&pg=PA23&lpg=PA23&dq=pei+greenwich+archaeology&source=bl&ots=nujuJ9XcSB&sig=BjJ23FiFO1acxDFCo631YNdRUaM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxzvTN687YAhVUyYMKHQG1BOc4ChDoAQhNMAg#v=onepage&q=pei%20greenwich%20archaeology&f=false |first=William G. |last=Scheller |journal=Islands Magazine |volume=19 |issue=6 |date=December 1999 |accessdate=January 10, 2018 |pages=23–24}} The park also encompasses [[Green Gables (Prince Edward Island)|Green Gables]], the inspiration for the popular ''[[Anne of Green Gables]]'' novels.{{rp|62–63}} |- ! scope=row|[[Pukaskwa National Park|Pukaskwa]] | [[Image:HorseshoeBayPukaskwaPark23.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|48|15|N|85|53|W|format=dms|name=Pukaskwa National Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 1971 | {{sort|{{commas|1878}}|{{convert|1878|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Central boreal uplands | Located on the [[Voyageur Hiking Trail]] and the longest stretch of undeveloped shoreline in the [[Great Lakes]],{{cite web |url=https://www.thestar.com/life/travel/2018/01/04/trekking-the-wild-shores-of-lake-superior-in-pukaskwa-national-park.html |title=Trekking the wild shores of Lake Superior in Pukaskwa National Park |first=Daniel |last=Otis |newspaper=Toronto Star |date=January 8, 2018 |accessdate=January 18, 2018}} Pukaskwa protects an area of boreal forest largely untouched by logging and mining industries, owing to the terrain's remarkable ruggedness. A large cluster of the [[Pukaskwa Pit]]s are located within the park. |- ! scope=row|[[Qausuittuq National Park|Qausuittuq]] | [[Image:Peary caribou - looking west towards Evan's Bay.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Nunavut}}
{{coord|76|00|N|100|00|W|format=dms|name=Qausuittuq National Park|region:CA-NU_type:landmark}} | 2015 | {{sort|{{commas|11008}}|{{convert|11008|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Western high Arctic |Located on [[Bathurst Island (Nunavut)|Bathurst Island]], the park is adjacent to the [[Polar Bear Pass National Wildlife Area]] and protects [[Peary caribou]] and [[muskox]] habitat. |- ! scope=row|[[Quttinirpaaq National Park|Quttinirpaaq]]{{efn|Ellesmere Island National Park Reserve was established in 1988, renamed Quttinirpaaq in 1999, and became a national park in 2000.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/quttinirpaaq-national-park/ |title=Quttinirpaaq National Park|publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia|accessdate=7 April 2008}}}} | [[Image:Tanquary Fiord 16 1997-08-05.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Nunavut}}
{{coord|82|13|N|72|13|W|format=dms|name=Quttinirpaaq National Park|region:CA-NU_type:landmark}} | 1988 | {{sort|{{commas|37775}}|{{convert|37775|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Eastern high Arctic | Located on the [[polar desert]] of [[Ellesmere Island]] at the northern tip of Canada, the park includes [[Tanquary Fiord]], [[Barbeau Peak]], [[Lake Hazen]], and [[Fort Conger]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Riding Mountain National Park|Riding Mountain]] | [[Image:Bison herd - Lake Audy - Riding Mountain National Park.JPG|175px|]] | {{flag|Manitoba}}
{{coord|50|52|N|100|02|W|format=dms|name=Riding Mountain National Park|region:CA-MB_type:landmark}} | 1929 | {{sort|{{commas|2968}}|{{convert|2968|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Southern boreal plains & plateaux | Part of the [[Riding Mountain Biosphere Reserve]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?code=CAN+04&mode=all |title=Biosphere Reserve Information – Canada – Riding Mountain |publisher=[[UNESCO]]|accessdate=7 April 2008}} the park features both boreal and aspen forests among the larger grassland prairie landscape, interspersed with [[Pothole (landform)|pothole lakes]] and marshes. The park has an [[outdoor recreation]] focus and includes the community of [[Wasagaming, Manitoba|Wasagaming]], the [[Riding Mountain Park East Gate Registration Complex|East Gate]] National Historic Site, and formerly the [[Whitewater (POW camp)|Whitewater prisoners-of-war camp]].{{cite book |title= Riding Mountain National Park of Canada and Riding Mountain Park East Gate Registration Complex National Historic Site of Canada Management Plan |publisher=Parks Canada |year=2007 |isbn= 0-662-43469-2}} |- ! scope=row|[[Rouge National Urban Park|Rouge]] | [[File:Pond at south end of Rouge 1.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|43|56|N|79|14|W|format=dms|name=Rouge National Urban Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 2015 | {{sort|{{commas|79.1}}|{{convert|79.1|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | St. Lawrence lowlands | Located in the [[Greater Toronto Area]] beginning at the mouth of the [[Rouge River (Ontario)|Rouge River]] and through the east end of [[Scarborough, Toronto|Scarborough]] and [[Markham, Ontario|Markham]], the park includes riparian corridors and wetlands with habitat for the [[Blanding's turtle]], as well as the site of the [[Bead Hill|Bead Hill National Historic Site]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Sable Island National Park Reserve|Sable Island]]
(Reserve) | [[Image:SableHorses.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Nova Scotia}}
{{coord|43|57|N|59|55|W|format=dms|name=Sable Island National Park Reserve|region:CA-NS_type:landmark}} | 2013 | {{sort|{{commas|30}}|{{convert|30|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Atlantic coast plain | Consisting of [[Sable Island]] at the edge of the [[continental shelf]] off the coast of [[Nova Scotia]], the island of sand is home to the [[Sable Island horse]] and provides habitat for [[grey seal]]s and [[Ammophila (plant)|beach grass]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Sirmilik National Park|Sirmilik]] | [[Image:Sirmilik Glacier 2 1997-08-06.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Nunavut}}
{{coord|72|59|N|81|8|W|format=dms|name=Sirmilik National Park|region:CA-NU_type:landmark}} | 2001 | {{sort|{{commas|22200}}|{{convert|22200|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Eastern Arctic lowlands{{cite book |title=Sirmilik National Park Management Plan |year=2016 |publisher=Parks Canada |accessdate=25 January 2018 |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nu/sirmilik/info/~/media/684CCA108D3443A09C18B54FA9B44C67.ashx}} | Located on the eastern end of Nunavut, Sirmilik consists of the [[Byam Martin Mountains]] of [[Bylot Island]] and [[Baffin Island]]'s [[Borden Peninsula]] and [[Oliver Sound]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Terra Nova National Park|Terra Nova]] | [[Image:NLC TerraNova3 tango7174.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Newfoundland and Labrador}}
{{coord|48|32|N|53|56|W|format=dms|name=Terra Nova National Park|region:CA-NL_type:landmark}} | 1957 | {{sort|{{commas|399}}|{{convert|399|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Eastern Newfoundland Atlantic region | The eastern-most national park, Terra Nova is located on the east coast of [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] along the [[Trans-Canada Highway]]. The park is characteristic of the Newfoundland landscape of low relief and rounded hills, and a rocky coastline of [[Arm (geography)|arms]], [[Sound (geography)|sounds]], [[cove]]s, [[inlet]]s, [[Natural arch|sea arches]], and caves, as well as habitat for the [[Newfoundland pine marten]].{{cite book |title=Terra Nova National Park of Canada Management Plan |publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |year=2009 |isbn= 978-1-100-10393-8}} |- ! scope=row|[[Thousand Islands National Park|Thousand Islands]] | [[File:Thousand Islands 2.JPG|175px]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|44|21|N|75|57|W|format=dms|name=Thousand Islands National Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 1904 | {{sort|{{commas|24}}|{{convert|24|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence lowlands | The park is scattered over all or portions of 26 islands and 80 [[islet]]s and [[shoal]]s in the [[St. Lawrence River]], as well as several mainland properties in [[United Counties of Leeds and Grenville|Leeds and Grenville]], east of [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]], and within the [[Frontenac Arch Biosphere Reserve]]. |- ! scope=row|[[Torngat Mountains National Park|Torngat Mountains]] | [[Image:Nachvak Fjord Labrador 2008.JPG|175px]] | {{flag|Newfoundland and Labrador}}
{{coord|59|26|N|63|52|W|format=dms|name=Torngat Mountains National Park|region:CA-NL_type:landmark}} | 2005 | {{sort|{{commas|9700}}|{{convert|9700|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Northern Labrador mountains | Located on the northernmost tip of [[Labrador]], adjacent to Quebec's [[Kuururjuaq National Park|Kuururjuaq Park]], and established as part of Inuit Land Claims Agreements, the park includes the [[Torngat Mountains]], [[Labrador Sea]] coastline, and [[Pre-Dorset]], [[Dorset culture|Dorset]], and [[Thule people|Thule]] archaeological finds.{{cite book |title=Torngat Mountains National Park Canada: management plan |publisher=Parks Canada |year=2010 |isbn= 978-1-100-13554-0}} |- ! scope=row|[[Tuktut Nogait National Park|Tuktut Nogait]] | [[File:Hornaday River.jpg|upright|175px]] | {{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{coord|68|49|N|121|45|W|format=dms|name=Tuktut Nogait National Park|region:CA-NT_type:landmark}} | 1998 | {{sort|{{commas|18181}}|{{convert|18181|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Tundra hills | Within the [[Inuvialuit Settlement Region]], the park was created to protect the Bluenose-West caribou herd and harvesting rights for the [[Inuvialuit|Inuvialuit people]]. It was expanded in 2005 to include a portion of the [[Sahtu Dene and Metis Comprehensive Land Claim Agreement|Sahtu Settlement Area]].{{cite book |title=Tuktut Nogait National Park of Canada: management plan |publisher=Parks Canada |year=2007 |isbn= 978-0-662-42988-3}} |- ! scope=row|[[Ukkusiksalik National Park|Ukkusiksalik]] | [[Image:Eisbär 1996-07-23.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Nunavut}}
{{coord|65|21|N|87|18|W|format=dms|name=Ukkusiksalik National Park|region:CA-NU_type:landmark}} | 2003 | {{sort|{{commas|20880}}|{{convert|20880|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Central tundra{{cite book |title=Ukkusiksalik National Park of Canada: Management Plan |url=http://pcacdn.azureedge.net/-/media/pn-np/nu/ukkusiksalik/WET4/info/Ukkusiksalik-National-Park-Management-Plan_Draft__2017_EN_Final-Web.pdf?la=en&modified=20170914191636&hash=FC54C200B74DDFB88E2E30D799D48A2D2A9CF9DC |publisher=Parks Canada |year=2017 |accessdate=25 January 2018}} | Named after the [[Inuvialuktun|Inuit]] word for [[soapstone]], the park surrounds [[Wager Bay]] which is [[maternity den]]ning areas for [[polar bear]]s and includes cultural relics of the [[Dorset culture|Dorset]] and [[Thule people|Thule]] and [[Aivilingmiut]] people. |- ! scope=row|[[Vuntut National Park|Vuntut]] | [[Image:Vontut National Park.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Yukon}}
{{coord|68|22|N|139|51|W|format=dms|name=Vuntut National Park|region:CA-YK_type:landmark}} | 1993 | {{sort|{{commas|4345}}|{{convert|4345|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Northern Yukon | Adjacent to the Ivvavik National Park and the American [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge]], the park area was not glaciated during the last ice age and now hosts [[Pleistocene]] fossil sites. Remote and inaccessible by road, the park was established, and is operated, in collaboration with the [[Vuntut Gwitchin First Nation]] as part of that nation's Final Agreement with Canada.{{cite book |title=Vuntut National Park of Canada Management Plan |publisher=Parks Canada |year=2010}} |- ! scope=row|[[Wapusk National Park|Wapusk]] | [[Image:Bärenmutter & Junges 3 2004-11-17.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Manitoba}}
{{coord|57|46|N|93|22|W|format=dms|name=Wapusk National Park|region:CA-MB_type:landmark}} | 1996 | {{sort|{{commas|11475}}|{{convert|11475|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Hudson—James lowlands | Created from a portion of the provincial Churchill Wildlife Management Area, Wapusk helps protect the land base that act as [[maternity den]]ning areas for [[polar bear]]s.{{cite book |title=Wapusk National Park of Canada Management Plan |publisher=Parks Canada |year=2007 |isbn= 978-0-662-47407-4}} |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Waterton Lakes National Park|Waterton Lakes]]‡{{efn|Waterton Lakes National Park is part of [[Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park]], a [[World Heritage Site]] which includes the adjoining [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]] in [[Montana]], United States.}} | [[Image:Upper Waterton Lake.JPG|175px]] | {{flag|Alberta}}
{{coord|49|03|N|113|55|W|format=dms|name=Waterton Lakes National Park|region:CA-AB_type:landmark}} | 1895 | {{sort|{{commas|505}}|{{convert|505|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Rocky Mountains | Coupled with American neighbour [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]] in [[Montana]], the [[Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park]] is both a World Heritage Site and the oldest [[transboundary protected area]] in the world. Anchored by [[Waterton Lake]], home of the historic [[Prince of Wales Hotel]], the park is famous for hiking attractions such as the [[Crypt Lake Trail]]. |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Wood Buffalo National Park|Wood Buffalo]]‡ | [[Image:Wood-Buffalo-NP Gros Beak Lake 2 98-07-02.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|Alberta}}
{{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{coord|59|23|N|112|59|W|format=dms|name=Wood Buffalo National Park|region:CA-AB_type:landmark}} | 1922 | {{sort|{{commas|44972}}|{{convert|44972|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Northern boreal plains |The largest park in Canada, the park protects the habitat of the [[wood bison]] and the breeding grounds of the [[whooping crane]] and much of the [[Peace–Athabasca Delta]]. It is also a World Heritage Site and the world's largest [[dark-sky preserve]]. |- | bgcolor=#cfecd2 scope=row|[[Yoho National Park|Yoho]]‡ | [[Image:YohoNP-Takakkaw IMG 1372-800x533byBMK.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|51|24|N|116|29|W|format=dms|name=Yoho National Park|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 1886 | {{sort|{{commas|1313}}|{{convert|1313|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Rocky Mountains | Part of the [[Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks World Heritage Site]] and adjacent to the Banff and Kootenay National Parks, Yoho includes the community of [[Field, British Columbia|Field]], [[Burgess Shale]] fossil deposit, [[Emerald Lake (British Columbia)|Emerald Lake]], [[Takakkaw Falls]], and [[Kicking Horse River]]. |} ===Proposed National Park Reserves=== The following are areas which Parks Canada is in the process of evaluating as potential parks. While they may be reserved from alienation or have federal-provincial/territorial agreements, they have not been formally established through legislation as parks. {| class="wikitable sortable" width=85% |- ! width=25%|Name ! width=10%|Location ! width=10%|Area ! width=15%|Natural region |- | Manitoba Lowlands{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/manitoba-lowlands-budget-1.4037241 |title=New Manitoba national park announced in 2017 budget home to white cliffs, turquoise lake |first=Laura |last=Glowacki |website=CBC News |date=22 March 2017 |accessdate=25 January 2018}} | {{flag|Manitoba}}
{{Coord|53|46|N|99|4|W|format=dms|region:CA-MB_type:landmark|name=Limestone Bay}} | Approx. {{sort|{{commas|5000}}|{{convert|5000|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}{{Cite web|url=http://manitobawildlands.org/pa_ntl_prks.htm |title=Manitoba National Parks |website=Manitoba Wildlands |date=30 May 2014 |accessdate=25 January 2018}} | Manitoba lowlands |- | South Okanagan—Similkameen{{cite web |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3829040/efforts-heat-up-to-create-a-national-park-in-the-south-okanagan/ |title=Efforts heat up to create a national park reserve in the south Okanagan |first=Blaine |last=Gaffney |website=Global News |date=27 October 2017 |accessdate=18 January 2018}} | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{Coord|49|4|N|119|41|W|format=dms|region:CA-BC_type:landmark|name=South Okanagan—Similkameen National Park Reserve}} | Approx. {{sort|{{commas|284}}|{{convert|284|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/cnpn-cnnp/okanagan |title=Proposed National Park Reserve in the South Okanagan-Similkameen|publisher=Parks Canada|date=18 January 2018|accessdate=18 January 2018}} | Interior dry plains |- | [[Thaidene Nene National Park Reserve (proposed)|Thaidene Nene]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/10/14/nwt-park.html |title=Ottawa, Dene agree to create vast national park|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=14 October 2006|accessdate=7 April 2008}} | {{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{Coord|62|30|N|111|00|W|format=dms|region:CA-NT_type:landmark|name=Thaidene Nene National Park Reserve}} | Approx. {{sort|{{commas|14000}}|{{convert|14000|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}{{Cite web|url=http://naturecanada.ca/news/press-releases/nature-canada-applauds-federal-governments-renewed-commitment-to-national-park-system/|title=Nature Canada Applauds Federal Government’s Renewed Commitment to National Park System|publisher=Nature Canada|date=16 October 2006|accessdate=7 April 2008}} | Northwestern boreal uplands{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/cnpn-cnnp/thaidene-nene/~/media/6EF042568A3049999C1C374A2F6B46F5.ashx |title=Thaidene Nëné Proposed National Park Reserve Ecological Values Summary |publisher=Parks Canada |accessdate=18 January 2018}} |} ===Abolished National Parks=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Name !width="25%"|Location !width=12.5%|Established !width=12.5%|Abolished |- | [[Whiteshell Provincial Park|Brereton Lake]]{{cite book |first=E. J. |last=Hart |title=J. B. Harkin: Father of Canada's National Parks |publisher=University of Alberta Press |location=Edmonton, AB |year=2010 |url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=MCGoAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=340}} | {{flag|Manitoba}} | {{dts|1922}} | {{dts|1930}} |- | [[Buffalo National Park]] | {{flag|Alberta}} | {{dts|1908|3|7|format=dmy}} | {{dts|1947|7|17|format=dmy}} |- | [[Menissawok National Park]]{{cite act |title=[[National Parks Act (Canada)|National Parks Act]] |type=Act |date=30 May 1930 |url=http://parkscanadahistory.com/publications/national-parks-act-1930.htm |accessdate=15 December 2017}} | {{flag|Saskatchewan}} | {{dts|1922|5|31|format=dmy}} | {{dts|1930|5|30|format=dmy}} |- | [[Nemiskam National Park]]{{cite book|author = Federation of Alberta Naturalists, Fish and Wildlife Historical Society|title = Fish, Fur & Feathers: Fish and Wildlife Conservation in Alberta 1905–2005 | page =100| year=2005|publisher=Nature books of Alberta|isbn = 0-9696134-7-4}} | {{flag|Alberta}} | {{dts|1914}} | {{dts|1947|7|17|format=dmy}} |- | [[Vidal Point Dominion Park]]{{cite book |url=http://parkscanadahistory.com/publications/history/lothian/eng/index.htm |chapterurl=http://parkscanadahistory.com/publications/history/lothian/eng/vol2/chap4.htm |title=A History of Canada's National Parks |chapter=Chapter 4: National Parks Administration (1885 to 1973) |volume=II |first=W. F. |last=Lothian |publisher=Parks Canada |year=1977 |pages=15–17}} | {{flag|Saskatchewan}} | {{dts|1921|10|31|format=dmy}} | {{dts|1930|5|30|format=dmy}} |- | [[Wawaskesy National Park]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.biology.ualberta.ca/bsc/news17_2/grasslands.htm|title=Project Update: Arthropods of Canadian Grasslands|publisher=[[University of Alberta]]|accessdate=7 April 2008}} | {{flag|Alberta}} | {{dts|1922|5|31|format=dmy}} | {{dts|1938|6|24|format=dmy}} |} ==National Marine Conservation Areas== [[National Marine Conservation Areas]] (NMCAs) are a relatively new invention in the park system. The goal of the NMCA system is to preserve areas representing Canada's 29 marine regions as identified by Parks Canada.{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/amnc-nmca/cnamnc-cnnmca/carte-map-txt |title=Completing the National Marine Conservation Areas System |publisher=Parks Canada |date=30 March 2017 |accessdate=25 January 2017}} They are designed for sustainable use, although they usually also contain areas designed to protect [[ecological integrity]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/amnc-nmca/plan|title=National Marine Conservation Area System|publisher=Parks Canada|date=20 July 2017|accessdate=15 December 2017}} [[Lake Superior National Marine Conservation Area]], created in 2015, is the only unit that uses this designation in its name. [[Fathom Five National Marine Park]] was created in 1987, prior to the NMCA concept, and subsequently classified as an NMCA without changing its legal name. [[Saguenay–St. Lawrence Marine Park]] is jointly administered by Parks Canada and its Quebec counterpart, [[Société des établissements de plein air du Québec|Sépaq]]. National Marine Conservation Area Reserves are protected areas proposed to be added to the NMCA system pending settlement of indigenous land and water rights. In the interim, they are administered under park rules. {{As of|2018}}, established NMCAs and NMCA Reserves protect {{cvt|14,846|sqkm}} of waters, wetlands, and coastlines, representing five of the 29 identified marine regions with studies underway for protected areas in three additional regions. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- |- !scope=col width=12%|Name !scope=col width=1%px class="unsortable"|Photo !scope=col width=8%|Location !scope=col width=8%|Established !scope=col width=8%|Area (2017) !scope=col width=8%|Marine region !scope=col width=18% class="unsortable"|Description |- | [[Fathom Five National Marine Park|Fathom Five]] | [[Image:Flowerpot Island Big Flowerpot.JPG|175px|]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|45|19|N|81|38|W|format=dms|name=Fathom Five National Marine Park|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 1987 | {{sort|{{commas|114}}|{{convert|114|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Georgian Bay | The marine counterpart to Bruce National Park, Fathom Five is named for a line in [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] ''[[The Tempest]]''. The first marine unit in the national parks system preserves a unique aquatic environment and several small islands including [[Flowerpot Island]]. The unusually clear waters and numerous shipwrecks on the [[shoal]]s of [[Georgian Bay]] make the park a popular destination for [[scuba diving|scuba divers]].{{rp|189}} |- |[[Gwaii Haanas National Marine Conservation Area Reserve and Haida Heritage Site|Gwaii Haanas]] (Reserve) | [[File:Fairfax Lake - panoramio.jpg|175px]] | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|52|0|N|131|12|W|format=dms|name=Gwaii Haanas National Marine Conservation Area Reserve|region:CA-BC_type:landmark}} | 2010 | {{sort|{{commas|10000}}|{{convert|1500|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.haidagwaiiobserver.com/news/minister-visits-celebrates-marine-parks-creation/ |title=Minister visits, celebrates marine park's creation |work=Haida Gwaii Observer |date=14 June 2010 |accessdate=15 December 2017}} | Hecate Strait, Queen Charlotte Shelf | Along with the national park reserve of the same name, Gwaii Haanas protects an area extending from the ocean floor of the [[Hecate Strait]] and [[Queen Charlotte Basin]] to the mountains of the [[Haida Gwaii]]. The marine reserve preserves the [[Haida people]]'s traditional use of the waters while protecting the area from [[oil exploration]] and commercial fishing.{{rp|299}} |- |[[Lake Superior National Marine Conservation Area|Lake Superior]] | [[File:Silver Islet ON.JPG|175px|]] | {{flag|Ontario}}
{{coord|48|26|N|89|13|W|format=dms|name=Lake Superior National Marine Conservation Area|region:CA-ON_type:landmark}} | 2007 | {{sort|{{commas|10880}}|{{convert|10880|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | Lake Superior | Adjacent to the United States' [[Isle Royale National Park]] and several [[List of Ontario provincial parks|Ontario provincial parks]], Lake Superior NMCA forms part of the world's largest [[freshwater]] reserve.{{cite web |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jV5wUUkH_NxhNSdrOOzUlh8c872A |title=Canada creates world's biggest water reserve |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=25 October 2007 |accessdate=23 January 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105022946/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jV5wUUkH_NxhNSdrOOzUlh8c872A |archivedate=5 January 2008}} |- | [[Saguenay–St. Lawrence Marine Park|Saguenay–St. Lawrence]] | [[Image:Fjord Saguenay.JPG|175px|]] | {{flag|Quebec}}
{{coord|48|4|N|69|40|W|format=dms|name=Saguenay–St. Lawrence Marine Park|region:CA-QC_type:landmark}} | 1998 | {{sort|{{commas|1245}}|{{convert|1245|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}}{{cite web |url=http://parcmarin.qc.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/CartePMSSL2016_webANG.pdf |title=Map of Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park |accessdate=17 February 2018 |format=PDF |publisher=Ministère du Développement durable, de l'Environnement et des Parcs du Québec }} | St. Lawrence Estuary | Located at the [[confluence]] of the [[Saguenay River|Saguenay]] and [[St. Lawrence River|St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence]] rivers and adjacent to Quebec's [[Saguenay Fjord National Park]], Saguenay–St. Lawrence protects a portion of the [[Estuary of Saint Lawrence|St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence estuary]], a common feeding ground for marine mammals such as the endangered St.{{nbsp}}Lawrence [[beluga whale]]. |} ===Proposed National Marine Conservation Areas=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! width=20%|Study area ! width=16%|Location ! width=16%|Area ! width=16%|Marine region |- | Magdalen Islands{{cite web |url=http://www.mddelcc.gouv.qc.ca/communiques_en/2012/c20120509-ilesdelamadeleine.htm |title=Study on the Creation of a Marine Protected Area in Îles-de-la-Madeleine |publisher=Government of Quebec |date=9 May 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/docs/pc/rpts/rmr-dpr/03312014/index |title=Departmental Performance Report |year=2014 |author=Parks Canada |accessdate=18 January 2018}} | {{flag|Quebec}}
{{coord|47|35|N|61|32|W|format=dms|name=Magdalen Islands|region:CA-QC_type:waterbody}} | {{sort|{{commas|16500}}|{{convert|16500|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | [[Magdalen Islands|Magdalen shallows]] |- | Southern Strait of Georgia (Reserve){{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/amnc-nmca/cnamnc-cnnmca/dgs-ssg/region-area |title=Feasibility Study for the Proposed Southern Strait of Georgia National Marine Conservation Area Reserve |publisher=Parks Canada |date=30 March 2017 |accessdate=15 December 2017}} | {{flag|British Columbia}}
{{coord|49|18|N|123|48|W|format=dms|name=Strait of Georgia|region:CA-BC_type:waterbody}} | {{sort|{{commas|1400}}|{{convert|1400|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | [[Strait of Georgia]] |- | Tallurutiup Imanga{{cite web |url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/amnc-nmca/cnamnc-cnnmca/lancaster/rapport-report |title=A National Marine Conservation Area Proposal for Lancaster Sound: Feasibility Assessment Report |author=Lancaster Sound National Marine Conservation Area Feasibility Assessment Steering Committee |publisher=Parks Canada |date=25 August 2017 |accessdate=25 January 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126012614/https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/amnc-nmca/cnamnc-cnnmca/lancaster/rapport-report |archive-date=26 January 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} | {{flag|Nunavut}}
{{coord|74|13|N|84|0|W|format=dms|name=Tallurutiup Imanga|region:CA-NU_type:waterbody}} | {{sort|{{commas|109000}}|{{convert|109000|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}}} | [[Lancaster Sound]] |- |} ==National Landmark== In addition to national parks, a [[National Landmarks (Canada)|National Landmarks]] program was established in 1978 but has not yet been expanded beyond a single property. Landmarks were intended to protect specific natural features considered "outstanding, exceptional, unique, or rare to this country. These natural features would typically be isolated entities and of scientific interest."{{Cite web|url=https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/nt/pingo/info/sec6|title=Pingo Canadian Landmark – Park Management|publisher=Parks Canada|date=15 June 2017|accessdate=15 December 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |- !scope=col width=12%|Name !scope=col width=1%px class="unsortable"|Photo !scope=col width=8%|Location !scope=col width=8%|Established !scope=col width=8%|Area (2017) !scope=col width=26%|Description |- | [[Pingo National Landmark|Pingo]] | [[Image:Pingos near Tuk.jpg|175px|]] | {{flag|Northwest Territories}}
{{coord|69|24|N|133|05|W|format=dms|name=Aulavik National Park|region:CA-NT_type:landmark}} | 1984 | {{convert|16|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} | Located on the shore of the [[Arctic Ocean]], Canada's only National Landmark preserves eight ice-cored mounds known as [[pingo]]s including Canada's largest, Ibyuk Pingo, along with other land and ice formations unique to the [[permafrost]] environment. |} {{Clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Geography of Canada}} Provincial parks are administered and funded by the provincial governments, however some provincial parks are categorized as ''[[national park]]s'' (Category II) under the [[IUCN]]'s Protected Area Management Categories. [[Gatineau Park]] in [[Quebec]] is another park under the jurisdiction of the federal government. However, it is managed by the [[National Capital Commission]], not Parks Canada, and is not considered part of the national parks system. * [[List of Canadian protected areas]] * [[List of UNESCO Biosphere Reserves in Canada]] * [[List of national historic sites of Canada]] * [[List of World Heritage Sites in Canada]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite book |title=Guide to the National Parks of Canada |publisher=National Geographic |location=Washington, D.C. |year=2017 |isbn=978-1-4262-1756-2}} }} ==External links== {{Commons category|National parks of Canada|National Parks of Canada}} *[https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np National Parks] of Canada *[https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/amnc-nmca National Marine Conservation Areas] of Canada *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ca World Heritage Sites in Canada] *[http://www.parksearch.ca Park Search Canadian Parks Locator] {{National parks of Canada}} {{Canada topics}} {{Authority control}} {{featured list}} [[Category:National Parks of Canada]] [[Category:Lists of national parks|Canada]] [[Category:Lists of protected areas of Canada| ]]

[[File:Newport UK location map.svg|thumb|200px|alt=Map of Newport within Wales|Map of Newport within Wales]] This is a list of the '''[[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) in the [[Newport, Wales|Newport]]''' [[Area of Search]] (AoS).<ref>{{cite web|title=County search of SSSIs|url=http://www.ccw.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/protecting-our-landscape/special-landscapes--sites/sites-search-results.aspx?lang=en|publisher=[[Countryside Council for Wales]]|accessdate=21 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305031552/http://www.ccw.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/protecting-our-landscape/special-landscapes--sites/sites-search-results.aspx?lang=en|archivedate=5 March 2014|df=}}</ref>
==History== This Area of Search was formed from parts of the previous AoS of Gwent.
== Sites == * [[Caldicot and Wentloog Levels|Gwent Levels]] ** [[Rumney, Cardiff|Rumney]] ** [[St. Brides Wentloog|St Brides]] ** [[Whitson]] ** [[Nash, Newport|Nash]] and [[Goldcliff, Newport|Goldcliff]] ** [[Redwick, Newport|Redwick]] * [[Newport Wetlands]] * [[Langstone, Newport|Langstone]]-[[Llanmartin]] Meadows * [[Parc Seymour]] Woods * [[Penhow]] Woodlands * Plas Machen Wood * [[River Usk]] - Lower Usk * [[Severn Estuary]]
==See also== * [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{SSSI AOS lists}}
